keyTakeAways: Torrential flooding in central and southeastern Mexico caused by tropical storms has led to at least 44 deaths, with some sources reporting up to 48.
The storms, linked to remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, triggered landslides and flooding across five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Death tolls by state: 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people are still missing, and around 320,000 people have experienced power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
Mexico’s President Claudia Sheinbaum mobilized the military for rescue operations and aid distribution, stating 'We will not leave anyone without support.'
Photos from the military show evacuations using life rafts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high waters.
This is part of a pattern of extreme rainfall in Mexico this year, with Mexico City recording its rainiest June in over two decades.
The remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond are cited as the primary cause of the heavy rains affecting central and southeastern regions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential rains from remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused widespread flooding and landslides in central and southeastern Mexico, resulting in at least 44 deaths and dozens missing. The hardest-hit states include Veracruz (18 deaths), Hidalgo (16), Puebla (9), and Queretaro (1). Around 320,000 people face power outages, and 16,000 homes are damaged. President Claudia Sheinbaum activated the military to carry out rescue missions and ensure aid reaches affected communities. The event is part of an ongoing pattern of extreme rainfall in Mexico, with Mexico City experiencing its rainiest June in over two decades, underscoring climate-related risks in the region.
